required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Perfusion Assessment Using BOLD MRI and PBV in Endovascular Treatment of Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Study: Perfusion Assessment Using Blood Oxygen Level Dependent Functional Magnetic Resonance Angiographic Imaging and Parenchymal Blood Volume Imaging in Endovascular Treatment of Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease

brief_summary.textblock: Current assessment of lower limb ischemia cannot reflect the location and degree of ischemia. Tissue perfusion assessment was used in the diagnosis and treatment of lower limb ischemia in this project, and the quantitative evaluation of ischemia degree was realized by using its advantages of quantitative analysis and perfusion imaging.

primary_outcome.measure: Perfusion of the index leg assessed by BOLD MRI before and after endovascular intervention.
primary_outcome.description: BOLD evaluates perfusion noninvasively and can be used for long-term monitoring and postoperative follow-up. Improving the perfusion assessment will improve the evaluation system for endovascular treatment of PAOD.

primary_outcome.measure: Perfusion of the index leg assessed by PBV before and after endovascular intervention.
primary_outcome.description: PBV can evaluate intraoperative perfusion quantitatively in real time.

secondary_outcome.measure: The relationship between perfusion and function of the lower limb in PAOD patients
secondary_outcome.description: The preoperative and postoperative motor functions of the patients were tested to analyze the functional impact of perfusion improvement.

study_pop.textblock: The study was conducted in PAOD patients aged 35 to 80 years with clinical symptoms such as claudication, resting pain, or ulceration, who were intended for endovascular treatment. Computed tomographic angiography disclosed the occlusive lesion in their target lesion. Subject with complex infrapopliteal lesions was excluded in order to reduce the influence of other variables.
